channel.title: The multiversity today
channel.description:
A series about today's large university and its complexities and problems as seen by students, faculty, alumni and employees.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Laws, Grants and Contracts
item.description: The federal and state governments play important roles in the multiversity. Graduate students, faculty, administrators, and trustees comment on these relationships.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: Where Do We Go From Here?
item.description: What will the multiversity be like 10, 20, 50, or 100 years from now? This program featured some serious and not-so-serious predictions from industry experts.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: We Run It
item.description: The responsibility for the goals and overall direction of the multiversity lies in the legislative and executive arms of the institution: a board of trustees and the administration. In this program, administrators and trustees discuss their responsibilities, goals, and problems.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: In Triplicate, Please
item.description: Nonacademic employees of the multiversity and the effect of their jobs on the institution and community; efforts to aid urban ghetto residents and the hard-core unemployed are discussed.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: Where Did It Come From?
item.description: Modern multiversities can trace their development back to the first university, which was launched over eight hundred years ago. This program highlights the first universities, how they developed in the United States, and their current goals.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: Professor, I Don't Understand...
item.description: The academic staff of today's modern multiversity are as varied as their backgrounds, special interests, tastes, and habits. On this program you will hear what six faculty members have to say about their profession and what it means to them to work in a multiversity.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: What Am I Doing Here?
item.description: Undergraduate students talk about their education, their goals, and their lives on the multiversity campus.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: It's a City
item.description: A multiversity campus is not just a collection of students, faculty and administrators surrounded by a town. It is in itself a city that shares problems with any city of its size--and has a few that belong to academic communities alone. A comparison of multiversities and cities, including physical plants, security and traffic, police and fire protection.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: I Feel Like I've Been Here Forever
item.description: Even after grade school and four years of college, graduate students face three to eight or more years of apprenticeship before they receive a doctorate degree and full acceptance in today's academic community. In this program, graduate students discuss their problems, education and goals. Also, faculty members comment on graduate work and the role of the graduate student in a multiversity.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: what Good Is It?
item.description: Multiversities usually divide their operations into three general categories--teaching, research, and service--in order to meet the needs of society. This program examines the relationship between multiversities and society: what it is and what it should be.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges

item.title: We Pay For It
item.description: The modern multiversity is a multi-purpose institution requiring a multi-million-dollar budget to maintain its operations and fulfill its obligations. Where do the millions come from that pay for the teachers, administrators, nonacademic employees, buildings, and land required by today's multiversity? Directly or indirectly, the money comes from you and me: citizens. In this program, alumni and citizens pay for and react to the multiversity.
item.dc:creator: Corrigan, Dennis
item.dc:subject: Universities and colleges
